misc.title: Young gamers in Japan are growing up with far less connection to Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest than previous generations. The main reason is simple: todayâ€™s mainline games take much longer to release
misc.text: Young gamers in Japan are growing up with far less connection to Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest than previous generations. The main reason is simple: todayâ€™s mainline games take much longer to release. A new numbered Final Fantasy or Dragon Quest now often arrives after 7â€“10 years. That means a child can complete all six years of elementary school without ever experiencing a fresh main entry in either series during their childhood. In earlier decades, both franchises released usually every 1â€“3 years. Kids would play a new game every couple of years as they progressed through school, building strong memories and deep attachment that lasted into adulthood. Via: automatonwest

misc.text: #ONEPIECE1174 From: @Mugiwara_23 : "So you can get an idea of how big Loki is when he transforms into a dragon: this giant Luffy is much smaller than just one of Lokiâ€™s horns in dragon form. If I say Dragon Loki is 50 times bigger than Dragon Kaidou, I think Iâ€™m still seriously underestimating it XD"

misc.title: ã€A deeper analysis from a native Japanese perspectiveã€‘ This time, the chapter title is â€œThe Strongest Thing in the World.â€ At first glance, the immediate impression is Loki. Just hearing that phrase,
misc.text: ã€A deeper analysis from a native Japanese perspectiveã€‘ This time, the chapter title is â€œThe Strongest Thing in the World.â€ At first glance, the immediate impression is Loki. Just hearing that phrase, it could even sound like a jab at Kaido, who was known as the â€œstrongest creature.â€ But thereâ€™s another meaning to this title that Iâ€™d like to focus on. In Japanese, when you use hiragana in places where kanji would normally be used, it can create a childlike tone. So writing it as â€œã›ã‹ã„ã§ä¸€ç•ªã¤ã‚ˆã„ã‚‚ã®â€ instead of using kanji gives it a softer, more childlike feeling. Because of that, this title may actually be written from the perspective of a child in Elbaph. For someone like Colon, that might mean Ripley; for someone like Bjorn, it might mean someone like Road â€” in other words, the person who feels strongest to them: a parent or someone close in their family. So the title could also be expressing that idea from a childâ€™s point of view.

items.text: ã€A deeper analysis from a native Japanese perspectiveã€‘ This time, the chapter title is â€œThe Strongest Thing in the World.â€ At first glance, the immediate impression is Loki. Just hearing that phrase, it could even sound like a jab at Kaido, who was known as the â€œstrongest creature.â€ But thereâ€™s another meaning to this title that Iâ€™d like to focus on. In Japanese, when you use hiragana in places where kanji would normally be used, it can create a childlike tone. So writing it as â€œã›ã‹ã„ã§ä¸€ç•ªã¤ã‚ˆã„ã‚‚ã®â€ instead of using kanji gives it a softer, more childlike feeling. Because of that, this title may actually be written from the perspective of a child in Elbaph. For someone like Colon, that might mean Ripley; for someone like Bjorn, it might mean someone like Road â€” in other words, the person who feels strongest to them: a parent or someone close in their family. So the title could also be expressing that idea from a childâ€™s point of view.
